cte_events.event_name: GMA | Maintaining Effective Communication | Thursday, June 5, 10:00am - 12:00pm | Virtual
Proctoring Your Exams Using Respondus Lock Down Browser
cte_events.event_facilitators:
Rebecca Schkade - Respondus
Dr. Armanto Sutedjo - Center for Teaching Excellence
cte_events.event_description:
This workshop is designed to provide instructors with a comprehensive understanding of Respondus, a proctoring tool for creating and managing online assessments. Participants will learn how to navigate the Respondus interface, create and customize exams, and implement best practices for online assessments.
By the end of the workshop, attendees will be equipped with the knowledge and skills to effectively use Respondus to enhance their online teaching and assessment strategies.
Learning Outcomes:
Participants will be able to:
1) Identify key features of Respondus Lock Down Browser for creating and managing proctored assessments for their course.
2) Build a proctored assessment in Canvas using Respondus Lock Down Browser.
3) Explore best practices for using Respondus Lock Down Browser to enhance the quality and integrity of their assessments.

Register Here: https://ers.tamu.edu/register.aspx?scheduleid=44783

cte_events.event_name: GMA | Aligning Expectations | Monday, June 9, 11:30am-1:00 Pm | Virtual

cte_events.event_facilitators:
Carlos Perez, Center for Teaching Excellence
Dr. Jamie Thompson, Center for Teaching Excellence
cte_events.event_description:
This session emphasizes the importance of digital accessibility and its impact on ensuring all students have access to content.The Final Rule, approved by the Department of Justice, requires that all digital content comply with the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.1 Level AA standards by April 24, 2026. This workshop will cover key accessibility standards and their impact on course content. Participants will also explore various assistive technologies that support students with disabilities. By the end of the session, you will have the knowledge and awareness needed to navigate the digital accessibility landscape.

Learning Outcomes: Participants will be able to:
1. Describe the importance of digital accessibility.
2. Review accessibility standards.
3. Evaluate the connection between some assistive technologies and content creation.

Register Here: https://ers.tamu.edu/register.aspx?scheduleid=44844

cte_events.event_name: Digital Accessibility Series – Session 1: What Is Digital Accessibility?
cte_events.event_facilitators:
Carlos Perez, Center for Teaching Excellence
Dr. Jamie Thompson, Center for Teaching Excellence
cte_events.event_description:
Back by popular demand, this series from the Spring 2025 semester returns. The recent Title II revision (the Final Rule) mandates that all digital content meet accessibility standards, ensuring usability for all users. This first session emphasizes the importance of digital accessibility and its impact on ensuring all students have access to content. The Final Rule, approved by the Department of Justice, requires that all digital content comply with the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.1 Level AA standards by April 24, 2026.

This workshop will cover key accessibility standards and their impact on course content. Participants will also explore various assistive technologies that support students with disabilities. By the end of the session, you will have the knowledge and awareness needed to navigate the digital accessibility landscape.

Learning Outcomes: Participants will be able to…
1) Describe the importance of digital accessibility.
2) Review accessibility standards.
3) Evaluate the connection between some assistive technologies and content creation.

Register Here: https://ers.tamu.edu/register.aspx?scheduleid=44784

cte_events.event_name: GMA | Promoting Professional Development | Wednesday, June 11, 1:00 Pm-2:30 Pm | Virtual

cte_events.event_facilitators: Reem Hussein, Center for Teaching Excellence
cte_events.event_description:
In this session, participants will review a step-by-step process to create a gradebook that accurately tracks students’ progress in the class, integrates with their teaching methods, and supports effective grading communication for their students.
Learning Outcomes: Participants will be able to…
1) . Describe the benefits of accurately setting up Canvas gradebook for both instructors and students.
2) Apply the step-by-step Canvas gradebook setup procedure.

Register Here: https://ers.tamu.edu/register.aspx?scheduleid=44789

elp_events.event_name: Microteaching Practice (English Language Proficiency)
elp_events.event_facilitators: Ginessa Payne, Center for Teaching Excellence
elp_events.event_description:
This workshop helps participants enhance their teaching and public speaking skills through microteaching demonstrations delivered in a low-risk environment. Each participant delivers a 5-minute presentation, receiving constructive feedback from a consultant and an undergraduate student on pronunciation, presentation structure, visual aids, nonverbal communication and more. By presenting in front of a friendly audience, participants develop confidence, and by observing peers’ presentations, they gain additional insight into best practices for comprehensible and well-developed presentations.

Learning Outcomes: 
Participants will be able to…
1. Construct and deliver short, well-structured and intelligible presentations.
2. Create a visual aid to support key points.
3. Identify areas for improvement in their own presentations and those of their peers.

elp_events.event_name: ELP Journal Club: A Conversation Circle For Text-Based Discussions
elp_events.event_facilitators: Michele Vick, Center for Teaching Excellence
elp_events.event_description:
Journal Club is designed for international TAs and faculty to gain confidence in reading aloud and leading and participating in classroom discussions about texts. Each week, participants will receive a short article two days ahead of time to prepare for our discussions. This workshop will focus on improving pronunciation, expanding vocabulary, and developing effective discussion strategies. Participants will also have the opportunity to lead discussions, enhancing their confidence and skills in academic settings.

Learning Outcomes: 
Participants will be able to…
1. Read aloud with comprehensible pronunciation and increased confidence.
2.Use key terms from academic texts accurately in discussions.
3. Effectively facilitate group discussions about various texts.
4. Employ turn-taking skills when participating in discussions.

elp_events.event_name: English Language Proficiency Practice Group For Instructors Summer 2025 (Session 5): Prominent Words And Discourse Cues
elp_events.event_facilitators: Ginessa Payne, Center for Teaching Excellence
elp_events.event_description:
Fifth in a series of workshops for international graduate students, faculty, post-docs, and visiting scholars. This interactive workshop teaches the intonation that speakers need in order to convey their intended message, with well-placed emphasis. Discourse cues (transition signals) are introduced as tools that help the audience follow the speaker’s logic.

Learning Outcomes:
Participants will be able to…
1. Distinguish content words (meaningful words) from function words (grammatical words).
2. Pronounce the prominent word within a phrase with the appropriate pitch, volume, length, and vowel quality.

elp_events.event_name: Conversation Circle For English Language Proficiency
elp_events.event_facilitators: Sarah Vargas, Center for Teaching Excellence
elp_events.event_description:
Conversation Circle is a supportive space for practicing spoken English through group discussions on cultural topics, including American university culture. Participants improve spontaneous speaking, active listening, and conversational turn-taking. Through communication with speakers from a variety backgrounds, they acclimate to different accents. The sessions promote social connections, intercultural dialogue, and a sense of belonging. The goal is to enhance English fluency, comprehension, and confidence.

Learning Outcomes:
Participants will be able to…
1. Employ effective spontaneous communication skills in social, academic and professional settings.
2. Elaborate on their viewpoints and opinions in group discussions.
3. Construct clear and well-structured responses during impromptu conversations.
4. Apply appropriate turn-taking and active listening techniques in casual group discussions and more formal academic discussions.

elp_events.event_name: Don’T Tense Up About Verb Tenses: Choosing The Right Tense To Communicate Effectively (English Language Proficiency)
elp_events.event_facilitators: Michele Vick, Center for Teaching Excellence
elp_events.event_description:
Grammatical errors can hinder successful spoken communication. Speakers can communicate more effectively when they utilize the appropriate verb tense. In this workshop, attendees will review and practice narrative verb tenses while discussing research and reviewing previously covered classroom topics. They’ll explore the pedagogical impact of reviewing prior learning. An optional assignment for extended practice will be available on Canvas.

Learning Outcomes: 
Participants will be able to…
1. Utilize narrative tenses to recall previous lecture material and discuss connections to current content.
2. Produce narrative verb tenses effectively in the discussion of research findings, choosing the appropriate tense to convey temporal relationships.
3. Facilitate review activities during lab sessions or lectures, utilizing appropriate narrative tenses to reiterate and reinforce key concepts covered in previous classes.

elp_events.event_name: English Language Proficiency Practice Group For Instructors Summer 2025 (Session 6): Asking Questions And Active Learning
elp_events.event_facilitators: Ginessa Payne, Center for Teaching Excellence
elp_events.event_description:
Sixth in a series of workshops for international graduate students, faculty, post-docs, and visiting scholars. This interactive workshop introduces Bloom’s Taxonomy and the “flipped classroom” approach where active learning takes place during class time. It encourages teachers to ask their students thought-provoking questions that are grammatically correct and pronounced with correct intonation..

Learning Outcomes:
Participants will be able to…
1. Distinguish lower-order thinking from higher-order thinking.
2. Generate questions appropriate for college students.
3. Pronounce wh- questions and yes/no questions with accurate grammar and appropriate intonation contours.

elp_events.event_name: Microteaching Practice (English Language Proficiency)
elp_events.event_facilitators: Michele Vick, Center for Teaching Excellence
elp_events.event_description:
This workshop helps participants enhance their teaching and public speaking skills through microteaching demonstrations delivered in a low-risk environment. Each participant delivers a 5-minute presentation, receiving constructive feedback from a consultant and an undergraduate student on pronunciation, presentation structure, visual aids, nonverbal communication and more. By presenting in front of a friendly audience, participants develop confidence, and by observing peers’ presentations, they gain additional insight into best practices for comprehensible and well-developed presentations.

Learning Outcomes: 
Participants will be able to…
1. Construct and deliver short, well-structured and intelligible presentations.
2. Create a visual aid to support key points.
3. Identify areas for improvement in their own presentations and those of their peers.

elp_events.event_name: English Language Proficiency Practice Group For Instructors Summer 2025 (Session 7): Answering Questions And Contrastive Stress
elp_events.event_facilitators: Ginessa Payne, Center for Teaching Excellence
elp_events.event_description:
Seventh in a series of workshops for international graduate students, faculty, post-docs, and visiting scholars. This interactive workshop equips teachers and presenters to respond to unexpected questions from an audience. It teaches the intonation that speakers need in order to make a point, with well-placed emphasis on contrasting words.

Learning Outcomes:
Participants will be able to…
1. Use a four-step process for fielding questions.
2. Pronounce contrasting words with pitch, volume, duration, and vowel quality that set them apart from other words.

elp_events.event_facilitators: Sarah Vargas, Center for Teaching Excellence
elp_events.event_description:

elp_events.event_name: English Language Proficiency Practice Group For Instructors Summer 2025 (Session 8): Linking Words And Leading A Discussion
elp_events.event_facilitators: Michele Vick, Center for Teaching Excellence
elp_events.event_description:
Eighth in a series of workshops for international graduate students, faculty, post-docs, and visiting scholars. This interactive workshop teaches the value of a well-managed class discussion and provides functional language for leading such a discussion. It also introduces a critical aspect of pronunciation, which is the linking of one word to the next..

Learning Outcomes:
Participants will be able to…
1. In a class discussion, react and respond appropriately to keep the discussion advancing.
2. Pronounce phrases with connected speech (linking consonant to consonant, linking consonant to vowel, and linking vowel to vowel across word boundaries).

elp_events.event_name: English Language Proficiency Practice Group For Instructors Summer 2025 (Session 9): Meet Undergraduate Students
elp_events.event_facilitators: Ginessa Payne, Center for Teaching Excellence
elp_events.event_description:
Ninth in a series of workshops for international graduate students, faculty, post-docs, and visiting scholars. This interactive workshop brings Aggie undergraduate students together with international grad students and instructors to discuss the classroom culture at Texas A&M and in other countries. Each group gains a better understanding of the other, leading to more effective communication in the classroom, lab, and office hours.

Learning Outcomes:
Participants will be able to…
1. Make small talk with someone from another culture.
2. Articulate the educational culture in universities in your home country.
3. Discover something new about another culture.

elp_events.event_name: English Language Proficiency Practice Group For Instructors Summer 2025 (Session 10): Microteaching
elp_events.event_facilitators: Ginessa Payne, Center for Teaching Excellence
elp_events.event_description:
Tenth in a series of workshops for international graduate students, faculty, post-docs, and visiting scholars. This interactive workshop provides a friendly environment in which to practice teaching a microlesson. Presenters field questions from the audience and then receive feedback from a peer and from a CTE-ELP consultant.

Learning Outcomes:
Participants will be able to…
1. Teach for five minutes with logical organization, clear pronunciation, appropriate body language, instructive visual aid, and engagement with the audience.
2. Respond effectively to audience questions.

elp_events.event_name: Conversation Circle For English Language Proficiency

elp_events.event_name: Suggestion Or Requirement? Use The Right Modal Verb To Give Clear Instructions (English Language Proficiency)
elp_events.event_facilitators: Michele Vick, Center for Teaching Excellence
elp_events.event_description:
Grammatical errors can hinder successful spoken communication. Speakers can communicate more effectively when they utilize the appropriate modal verbs (such as should, might, must) to convey obligations and suggestions. In this workshop, attendees will review and practice modal verbs in the context of giving instructions and corrective feedback. An optional assignment for extended practice will be available on Canvas.

Learning Outcomes: 
Participants will be able to…
1. Review different modal verbs (such as should and have to) and compare their functions.
2. Demonstrate ability to use appropriate modal verbs to give instructions, conveying specific meaning and fostering clarity and understanding in the lab setting.
3. Discuss best practices for giving corrective feedback.
4. Employ modal verbs in the feedback process, showcasing the ability to convey constructive criticism and suggestions using appropriate modals.
